articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Ukrainian soldiers were observed using North Korean rockets that they said were seized by a "friendly" country before being delivered to Ukraine, the Financial Times reported on Saturday.
articles.title: Ukraine uses North Korean rockets to blast Russian forces, Financial Times reports

articles.author: Mike Stone, Idrees Ali
articles.description: The United States unveiled a Taiwan weapons aid package worth up to $345 million on Friday, a move likely to anger China even as the Biden administration declined to publicly provide details on the arms in the package.
articles.title: US announces Taiwan weapons package worth up to $345 million

articles.author: Liz Lee, Jenny Wang, Ryan Woo
articles.description: Rain soaked northern China on Saturday as Doksuri, one of the strongest storms to hit the country in years, prompted thousands to evacuate in Beijing after pummelling the Philippines and Taiwan, and lashing China's coast.
articles.title: Weaker Doksuri drenches north China, Beijing evacuates thousands

articles.author: Ngouda Dione
articles.description: Senegal's opposition leader Ousmane Sonko was charged on Saturday with plotting an insurrection, criminal conspiracy and other offenses, two months after his trial for a separate rape charge sparked deadly riots across the country.
articles.title: Senegal opposition leader Sonko charged with plotting insurrection

articles.author: Graham Keeley
articles.description: Spain's Socialists have emerged with one seat fewer after counts of votes from abroad in last week's election, making it harder for them to be able to form a left-wing coalition as they would need the support of hardline Catalan separatists rather than just their abstention, analysts told Reuters on Saturday.
articles.title: Socialists lose seat, after expat vote count, making it harder to form government

articles.author: Ruma Paul
articles.description: Bangladesh police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at stone-throwing opposition party supporters blocking major roads in the capital Dhaka on Saturday to demand the prime minister’s resignation.
articles.title: Bangladesh police clash with opposition supporters calling on PM to resign

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Nicolas Petro, son of Colombian President Gustavo Petro, has been arrested as part of an investigation into money laundering and illicit enrichment, the attorney general's office said early on Saturday.
articles.title: Colombia President Petro's son arrested in money laundering probe

articles.author: Jarrett Renshaw
articles.description: Vice President Kamala Harris has shown a punchy side during a tour of nearly a dozen U.S. states in recent weeks, attacking Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for backing "revisionist history" about slavery, telling Iowa healthcare workers to rebel against the state's new restrictive abortion laws and rallying Latinos in Chicago to fight "extremist" Republicans.
articles.title: Kamala Harris embraces new attack role, draws fresh Republican fire

articles.author: Andrew Osborn
articles.description: Wagner mercenary boss Yevgeny Prigozhin, who remains active despite leading a failed mutiny against the Russian army's top brass last month, has hailed Niger's military coup as good news and offered his fighters' services to bring order.
articles.title: 'Exiled' Russian mercenary boss Prigozhin hails Niger coup, touts services

articles.author: Ben Winck
articles.description: Two U.S. lawmakers have an idea for reining in Big Tech: get someone else to do it. Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren and her Republican peer Lindsey Graham proposed a new commission for policing technology firms on Thursday. Silicon Valley is indeed posing novel challenges, from privacy to mental health. A tech-focused super-regulator would be a great way to fail to fix these problems.
articles.title: Big Tech super regulator would be a super dud
